review: Un beat them all comme je les aime bien, des graphismes avec un style unique dans son genre à la Killer Instinct, on y trouve quelques références par rapport aux beat them all que l'on a connu: l'effet du coup batte de base ball  sur un ennemi par rapport a Vendetta, les motards qu'on peut désarçonner comme dans Renegade, etc... Quand au scénario, il n'est pas très recherché mais bon... Marrant pour se défouler à deux pour passer un bon moment. On a le choix entre 3 personnages avec leurs style et leur panel de coups. Les ennemis seront toujours les mêmes dans pratiquement tous les niveaux sauf les boss. Il y a des défi à remporter dans chaque stage qui ne se révèle pas si simple que ça. Je trouve bidon de remettre certains boss alors que l'on les a déjà battu. La difficulté y est ce n'est aussi facile que ça et les mobs peuvent vous être parfois relous. Ce n'est pas le beat them all par excellence, mais vous y passerez un bon momrent.

Además, la falta de variedad de golpes es otro problema importante en Raging Justice. Los personajes solo tienen un conjunto limitado de movimientos, y no se puede hacer gran cosa más...
Aclaro, que no tengo la verdad absoluta y es mi humilde opinión.

author: {'steamid': '76561198154214698', 'num_games_owned': 593, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 3544, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 470, 'last_played': 1673726539}
review:
比接管这种半吊子还要差，平衡性和爽快感都巨差，很纯粹的恶心人。
剧情不用说，无视就行，我觉得英雄救美已经很老套，它连这个都没有。
平庸的美术，角色像随便设计的，敌人之间的关系看上去都不挨着。
人物动作帧太少不流畅，导致不管哪方走动出招都看上去别扭。
动作设计等于没有，完全的王八拳。
敌人杂兵来来回回就6种的换色：
1-普通男 
2-普通男换服装的版本，没感觉有什么区别
3-普通女
4-炸弹男，扔炸弹的频率非常高，地上随时有炸弹
5-第一关boss
6-第二关boss
对的，2个boss被拿来当普通杂兵出场。
总共9关，里面除了2关的会被拿来当杂兵，还有3关是重复的boss，真正只用一次的boss只有最后一关。
敌人的攻击会打到自己人，会看到满场敌人被自己人痛殴，除了破坏玩家攻击策略外没多少意义。
2种有招数霸体的boss充数小兵也是出场率非常高满场串，玩家很容易被各种杂兵打倒，前面2种boss杂兵只要霸体出来打到你必然倒地，炸弹炸到你也倒地，连最普通的男女杂兵出拳打你都是要连到你倒地的，想后退都是没办法的，还无法普通拳脚还击，最好费血放保险解决，而放保险对敌人的伤害比一下普通攻击还低，自己费的血竟然接近四分一的量，爽快感很低。
每关都有挑战，挑战是不可能一次都做完的，都得刷，还有很大的运气成分才能完成，逮捕罪犯因为上述的那些原因挺难办，杂兵被揍晕倒地时不能逮捕，得站起来的时候你才能逮捕，他们自己还会互伤，在人多时很难把握到时机，非常愚蠢的设计。挑战需要逮捕的罪犯出场时会闪红光标示出来，但是一会就没了，混在一堆重复的杂兵里，根本就看不出来谁是谁了，傻逼透顶。
币用光了再继续游戏进关卡是只有你之前进关卡的血量和币量，美其名曰“这样当你通关时你就不会觉得自己滥用了系统。”，换句话说，你最后死的这关打不过的话只能背板硬过，无法像街机靠投币堆命，要不然就去前一关重新打，尽量留命。
成就系统也挺恶心，明晃晃的让你刷时间，难度还非常高，非常重复。

review:
It's quite difficult and has a learning curve but this is a pretty decent beat em up, once you've adapted to the play style.

The two things that really make it stand out from others in the genre are:

1. The best way to get health is to arrest enemies. Grab them, stun them, then arrest them when they get back up. This adds another layer of strategy to things and is something you really want to do when there's less enemies on screen.

2. You can continue from the start of any level you reach, but only with the lives and credits you had when you got there. This gives you a strong incentive to replay early levels in short bursts and improve your performance, which is a great way to add replayability to a beat em up.

Better than I was expecting and I'm glad I finally picked it up.

review: This pile of junk isn't even worth the sale price, and the 15 dollar retail price is a robbery. The game's controls are very limited and stiff, with few attacks or movement options. review:
Espanca ladrão, prende ladrão... espanca ladrão, prende ladrão... 

Um misto de nostalgia com raiva dos tempos de controle travado, é inegável que Raging justice é divertido e inegável que ele é travado como os games em que ele se baseia; o mundo arcade de antigamente tinha muitos erros de ser espancado por não ter visão do adversário ou simplismente por que você não sabe qual linha de visão esta. 
E isso é ruim?? Não, até que é bom relembrar as formas antigas de games e esse consegue resgatar isso. 

E podendo jogar cooperativo local, a coisa tende a ser mil vezes melhor né
Convenhamos que nada mais agradável que jogar em casa com alguém que esta visitando ou familiar? é algo que ainda é receita para boas risadas. 

Raging justice tem uma leve história de pano de fundo, onde uma cidade corrupta e inescrupulosa esta tomada pelo caos e desordem, cabe a algum dos nossos 3 policiais enfrenta tudo na base da porrada, ou atropelando inimigos com nosso cortador de grama.

De diferente das jornadas beat'up temos os empurrão onde serve como nossa defesa, e quando vemos inimigos atordoados podemos prende-los e assim ganhar recompensa de vida. 
A sensação que temos que tudo é muito simples para ficar na vibe de anos 90, mais acredito que falto uma boa árvore de upgrades ou skins para os personagens, fica chato juntarmos moeda na campanha e não termos onde gastar.

Com a proximidade de mais uma promoção de inverno para nós brasileiros, é um game simples e divertido que rende boas horas de jogatina, e se tem irmãos, primos ou visita de amigos; é aquele tipo de jogo bom para se ter instalado e zerarem enquanto esperam o lanche chegar.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046595924', 'num_games_owned': 4787, 'num_reviews': 115, 'playtime_forever': 81, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 81, 'last_played': 1647814029}
review:
My Video Review:
https://youtu.be/XJG7998caMU

Raging Justice is not a bad beat ‘em up game but could have definitely been better with a little bit more effort put into it. I have found quite a lot of pros there - dynamic neverending action, satisfactory effect of weapons, partially interactive environment, solid variety of enemies including bosses, balanced difficulty, responsive controls and solid graphics and sounds. But I have also found many cons there - that everyone is going after you at the same time logic which almost does not give you a chance to think through your attacks, slowness of your character, strange hitboxes sometimes, absence of any character development or something else that would enhance the gameplay and generic music. Is Raging Justice suitable for family playing? Well, it contains local multiplayer (which is another plus by the way), the stages are short and the gameplay is dynamic enough so the answer is yes.

Pros: 
- dynamic action
- weapons effect
- environment
- variety of enemies
- difficulty
- controls
- local multiplayer

Cons:
- everyone is going after you at the same time
- slowness of your character
- hitboxes
- absence of character development
- no dubbing
- music

I would lie if I say that I would not have enjoyed the game but it would be even more enjoyable without some controversial decisions that spoil the gameplay. I am giving Raging Justice Thumb Up and VideoGaming Father’s Index 7- out of 10 - recommended with some discount.

review:
Not really sure why there is so many negative reviews.
 It's a indie beat'em up with a retro vibe! Raging justice is hella similar to Final fight but managed to make it slightly better. 
The only con that I have with this game is that the arrest gimmick should be more dynamic like: Being able to arrest enemies while they are on the ground. 
Also there is times that the game throws at you tons of enemies to deal with that can knock you and stun, so this means that you can take a couple of hits while on the ground for no reason even if you commited a small mistake or keep getting stunned by the ladies over and over again. This game should have a move to break the enemy animations and add a invicible frame to a special attack similar to what Fight'n rage does.
I'll rate this a 6/10. Hella fun to play and if you are into beat'em ups you'll have a good time with this one.

review:
An awful beat'em'up, that could have  worked as a simple arcade game, but ultimately doesn't

I had a bit of fun playing it, and learning the ropes in the first couiple levels. With a bit more application they could have made this an enjoyable arcade game, even if it is way too janky to ever reaching the category of good beat'em ups.
First the base price is too high for what it has to offer. Don't pay more than 4$ for this. Preferably less.

This game looks like the game that Team 17 always dreamed of releasing in the early 90s but couldn't because the Amiga was not powerful enough.
The graphics are very nice, the stylized pre-rendered 3D style is weird but I like it. I can see that some players won't like it though. 
The gameplay is what you'd expect from a clone of final fight, with one added mechanism : the arrest. You can arrrest the thugs and it gives you a bit of life. In fact this is going to be the main mechanism in the game and the only way to progress further is to learn how to stun and arrest a lot of enemies.
The collisions are a very imprecise. The enemies are constantly stun locking you, and surounding you with too many enemies seems to be the main theme in the level design.
When it's not the enemies stunlocking you it's your own character with the bad placement or the stupid animations that almost never do what you intended to.
The gameplay is awful and the more you play the game, the more you'll hate it. That said , you can probably finish it if you are a masochist and put your heart to it and there are a lot of achievements to get, if you're this type of "people".
But the accumulation of repeating enemies toward the end becomes really stupid.

author: {'steamid': '76561198189899943', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 127, 'playtime_forever': 97, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 97, 'last_played': 1604452118}
review:
Raging Justice es un juego programado por ex-empleados de Rare, por lo tanto una pequeña fracción de aquella compañía que se destruyó en mil pedazos estaremos disfrutando en este juego, esperando y deseando que ojalá cada uno de esos fragmentos pueda fortalecerse por separado para que algún día, quién sabe, puedan volver a unirse y convertirse en ese todo que tanto extrañamos.

Aunque el género del Beat´em Up dé la impresión de estar sobre-explotado y que ya está todo dicho, siempre habrán quienes logren reinterpretar aquellas ideas viejas y sacarlas adelante con aportes propios, aunque muchos podrán comparar este juego con Double Dragon o Final Fight, la verdad es que Raging Justice bebe directamente de las fuentes de Vendetta y P.O.W., ambos de arcade. y complementándolo con unos gráficos renderizados que junto con aquella animación acartonada del primer Killer Instinct nos da la sensación de que estamos ante un juego 100% noventero y 100% Rare.

Lamentablemente y a juzgar por los antecedentes de que este juego fué hecho por un equipo pequeño que encima lo programó en su tiempo libre, no va a destacar por su pulcritud debido a que la variedad de enemigos resulta algo escasa, por lo que no es de extrañarnos que durante el juego estés enfrentando a 5 personajes repetidos simultáneamente, esa problemática de la variedad que se viene arrastrando desde el primer Double Dragon había sido resuelto con un simple cambio en la vestimenta de los enemigos, aquí ni a eso atinaron.
Sobre los protas, pues tampoco se esforzaron en haberlos dotado de un carisma que los haga recordables, por ende nos vamos a olvidar de ellos apenas completemos el juego y saquemos todos los logros (y eso si es que vamos a llegar tan lejos, pues la mayoría de ellos se obtienen terminando el juego cumpliendo ciertos requisitos).
Aunque debo decir que jugablemente se siente un poco más satisfactorio que Fighting Rage ya que los valores de los golpes se perciben más contundentes, algo que también ayuda bastante es que los personajes están perfectamente proporcionados y eso le aumenta el realismo.
El control de los personajes se nota que fué algo bastante estudiado, pues está pensado para que lo juegues de la forma minimalista usando los 4 botones de enfrente (golpe, patada, salto y agarre) o complicándote un poco más usando los botones índices para hacer movimientos que perfectamente puedes reemplazar por movimientos combinados de la cruceta (taclear derecha e izquierda y movimiento especial) y todo esto sin necesidad de ir a la pantalla de configuración.
El sistema de agarres es algo que podría ser discutible, personalmente prefiero el de Final Fight por ser más simple, mientras que aquí lo haces con un botón de agarre y con el que puedes combinar patadas y golpes o simplemente lanzarlos lejos.
Sobre el tema de las armas, pues aquí hicieron una fiesta con ellas, en todo momento tendrás disponibles martillos, bates, cuchillos, caimanes, dinamita, escopetas, cajas, bocatomas de agua, etc, una idea que me pareció estupenda y que no recuerdo haber visto antes es el poder montar vehículos (como tractores o carros de golf) para atropellar a tus enemigos, aunque este uso es bastante limitado.

Una cosa que se le podría criticar a este tipo de juegos está en la monotonía misma y en la nula variedad de las misiones, en épocas pasadas hubieron quienes metían escenas de Bonus destruyendo vehículos o vidrios gruesos, otros que metían escenas de 2D o incluso plataformeo pero manteniendo la jugabilidad, otros metían escenas donde manejabas vehículos en tercera persona, y hubieron quienes metían escenas arriba de un tren o en la parte trasera de un camíón, pues aquí te puedes olvidar de eso, pues en los 10 escenarios con los que cuenta todos tratan de lo mismo, una lástima.

Aún así el juego merece la pena, posee cooperativo de tres jugadores en local o en línea, tabla de calificaciones online, modo de desafío, caminos alternativos, y aunque la historia tampoco tiene nada del otro mundo, posee un pequeño plot-twist cuando llegamos con el jefe final, y una vez terminado el juego hay una pequeña [spoiler]promesa de una secuela.[/spoiler]

Sin ninguna duda recomendado.

author: {'steamid': '76561198250544676', 'num_games_owned': 3672, 'num_reviews': 323, 'playtime_forever': 28, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28, 'last_played': 1597683669}
review:
It doesn't take long to realise something is not quite right about Raging Justice. Upon loading up the game you are greeted by a title screen where our heroes and heroines all strike macho poses- so far so good. But....and I can't believe I'm typing this....where's the gruff voiced dude, who sounds like he gargles with rusty tetanus infested nails, saying "Raaaaaaaaaaaaagingggggg Juusssssticcccccce" with such intensity you'll be left in no doubt as to how RAGING this JUSTICE is gonna be, as one of them powerfully punches the games logo onto the screen?

They just pop up with barely a polite hello and some words appear, and from these words one comes to the conclusion that the game is called Raging Justice. As first impressions go it's a bit lame, but at least it's an accurate representation of the levels of pizazz the game brings to the scrolling beat em up genre. Which is to say very little.

It's in 3d, so you'd think that would lessen some of the issues games like this had in 2d. Fuck all frames of animation? That's a thing of the past...and, uh....the present too apparently, as characters aren't exactly silky smooth in their movement. Lack of attack moves that could have, once upon a time, been blamed on a lack of storage space or memory? (such as a console cart, or tiddly amount of ram) uh.....I really couldn't say why this has a dodge roll move, yet has no parries like Super Double Dragon even though it was 26 years old when this game was released.

Is avoiding being punched in the face, or kicked in the head or testicles, really such a bad thing? Is there some reason that a fundamentally large part of the combat of something like the Rocksteady Batman games should be ignored in a genre that's exactly the same gameplay but viewed from a fixed perspective? It really seems like it ought to be a staple mechanic by now, along with the dodge move, and the two should serve different functions. But nope...no parrying here.

Graphically it's a case of the emperors new clothes: it looks a bit nicer than most 2d beat em ups, but underneath those clothes its still wrinkly and shrivelled 30 year old gameplay. Sonically they miss a trick too, as the sound effects don't really sell the brutality of blows, or smashing someone in the head with a baseball bat (not that I personally know what that last one sounds like). 

Without the cathartic ultra violence of something like Batman Returns, the crunching of face into lamppost, or heads shoved into windows and bounced off park benches, it's just "walk left and right, press a button, and if you're lucky the hit detection will decide you punched or kicked someone". And it doesn't really matter where you hit them either: I once brutally pummelled someones feet after knocking them to the floor, and they died. 

One of the ladies got punched in the baby baker, and died. Once that automatic animation kicks in you can be hitting them in some odd places.....If you ever wanted to kill someone by punching them to death in the butt then this is the game for you

I did have a modicum of fun bashing hoodlums in with everything but the kitchen sink: fire hydrants, baseball bats, bottles, knives, hammers, traffic cones.....it's got a lot of weapon variety. The move set is passable, and it is responsive, so technically it just makes the grade.

But I quit playing when I got to a boss who looked like Andre The Giant, and was supposed to be a pimp, but came over as some weird cross between a matador and a pimp dressed in ugly garish purple clothes. As this boss constantly zipped out of range of every attack, and never gave me a chance to hit them, FOR 5 SOLID MINUTES....I got a tad pissed off with the game. Another glitch? or just shit design? and who the fuck cares anyway when the game is this mediocre?

As scrolling beat em ups go its alright. Scruffy and unpolished, but also simple and fun violence. As a genre though I personally find it far less compelling than I used to, and there are many examples of fighting combat taken to another level that are evolutions of this format. The Batman Arkham games, or Bayonetta, Devil May Cry, Furi etc offer the same mechanics, but in a fully fleshed out environment that utilises the space for extra elements - such as platforming / exploration / puzzle solving. 

If you just want to play for a few minutes and mindlessly duff up some neer'do'wells then this will cut the mustard, but overall I find the genre a bit tired now and this is not a game even attempting to rejuvenate it. Nor does it have the slick execution to gloss over its stunted gameplay. I'd recommend Double Dragon Neon, or the Capcom Beat Em Up Collection,  over it if you absolutely want a scrolling beat em up.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981638563', 'num_games_owned': 4007, 'num_reviews': 518, 'playtime_forever': 4849, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 92, 'last_played': 1596655546}
review:
Yet another one of those cheap and ugly beat 'em ups you shouldn't really care about. But let's start with the good stuff. First of all – this game actually works. Sounds like an obvious thing, but nowadays? In [b]Steam[/b]? That's actually a thing to mention. Too many cheap games here were made just for quick money and, as we all know, very often such products don't even work properly. [b]Raging Justice[/b] does. It won't crash on you or something like that. You want to finish it? You'll be able to. The problem is... most likely you won't want to. Even though this game? It does come with a couple of unique features.

In [b]Raging Justice[/b] you play as a wannabe cop (there are three generic characters to choose from). Which isn't really a big surprise, since we're often playing as cops in this kind of games. What's interesting here is that we can actually arrest people. In a way that reminds me a little bit of [b]RoboCop 2[/b] from the [b]NES[/b] (weird comparison, I know, but still).You stun the enemy – you can arrest him, or her for better score. And there are also challenges. Every level has a series of optional objectives you can complete. Finish the level in certain time, arrest a certain number of enemies, etc. Finally, you can achieve bad or good cop status by approaching the enemies in a certain way. Again, all for the better score. And that's the thing about unique features in [b]Raging Justice[/b]. Technically, they're here. And technically, they're pretty interesting. But the thing is - they just can't change your opinion. Because those are all about score and if you don't like the core gameplay? You just won't care about them. Like... at all.

And the core gameplay? Let's just say it's far from being good. And not only because the game looks ugly. I mean, it sure does and it ruins the mood quite a lot. Instead of being stylish, [b]Raging Justice[/b] just looks... unpleasant. But the real problem is – everything here feels wrong. It's a bit too slow, the moves take a bit too long to perform, balance is all over the place, the weapons often feel useless, etc, etc, etc. It's nothing big, but when you combine all those little things? You get a pretty unpleasant result.

Sure, nowadays we don't get new beat 'em ups often. It's one of those “extincted” genres. So, technically, new games of such kind are always welcomed. Unfortunately, [b]Raging Justice[/b] just doesn't worth it. Even though it costs only [b]£9.99[/b], the game just fails to satisfy. I mean, beat 'em up genre is all about – satisfaction. Feeding the baddies your strong fists should feel good. In this game? It doesn't. Should I say more?

review:
Raging Justice est un homage aux jeux de baston des années 90 tels que Final Fight ou Street of Rage.
La réalisation est celle qu'on aurait rêvé d'avoir à l'époque, avec des énormes personnages "digitalisés" de toute beauté !
Avec ses bruitages faits à la bouche et tous les clichés bien ringards, ce jeu est un nanar réussi.

Petit problème à signaler dans la jouabilité quand même, puisque le bouton pour arrêter les ennemis sans les tuer est le même que pour ramasser un objet ou projeter un ennemi. Donc on ratera la plupart des arrestations, mais ça n'empêche pas d'aller au bout du jeu.
Au delà de ce petit souci, c'est un très bon jeu pour retrouver les sensations de l'époque.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010315744', 'num_games_owned': 1309, 'num_reviews': 725, 'playtime_forever': 140, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 117, 'last_played': 1578093049}
review:
A bit baffled on this game and it's "Very Positive" rating here...There are a lot of problems with this game, especially with there being so many good templates to follow from older games like Streets of Rage 2 and Final Fight. This game feels like it just ignores just about all the good parts of those games and it's a complete mess.
Let's get the worst out of the way first...you know how in classic beat-em-ups if you're fighting an enemy the others on screen mostly hang back for a second and let you do your thing? Not here. Almost every enemy comes after you all at once with no breathing room. To make matters worse, when you get hit, land on the ground and recover there's usually a small bit of invincibility so you actually have a fighting chance. In this game you can get hit and fall to the ground, get up and you get smothered instantly. Over and over. And regular enemies do way to much damage. And this is all in Normal difficulty too. Once you run out of continues there's a game over, but you can jump back to the last stage you were in but only get couple lives with no continues so I don't see the point there. I made it to stage 8 and used all my continues. I tried changing the difficulty to Wimp, but it greyed out all the stages (except stage 1)because I didn't complete them on that specific difficulty- even though I already beat them on normal. Dumb.

Graphics are ok, but animations are a little on the janky side. The color palette is just bland too. It got really easy to get lost on where my character was in the screen when theres 7 or 8 characters on screen at once. The camera also moves slightly up and down depending on where you are onscreen and sometimes zooms in and out a little which became irritating fast. Setting the camera with no movement at all would've been much better.

The whole "good cop, bad cop" idea is cool on paper, but extremely tedious to pull off. You can only arrest bad guys if they have dizzy stars over their head, (think SF II), but you can't see this until they get up. Enemies can also attack each other indirectly like a knife being thrown which can hit the guy you're trying to arrest, cause them to hit the ground and when they get back up suddenly they're not dizzied anymore for whatever reason. Combined with the already mentioned enemies all coming you at once, it's very frustrating to pull off a lot of the time. What's even worse is the game wants you to go this route because you get health pickups after arresting people and if you just kill them you get nothing. And being called a "bad cop" just because you killed someone who has an arrest warrant is just stupid...I mean, you're fighting tons of bad guys on the street and that's ok, but as soon as you kill someone who has a warrant suddenly you're a bad cop? In a beat-em-up game??? C'mon.

I tried all three characters. I was expecting like SoR where you'd have a strong but slow character (Adam), a balanced one (Axel), and a faster but weaker damage one, (Blaze). But they all kind of felt the same with no significant difference. Maybe I'm wrong here, but it also felt like I was moving a little slower if I had a weapon equipped too.

Moving on to sound, the music ktrues to emulate Final Fight, but a much more bland and boring version. All the tracks are nothing special and are easily forgettable. The sound effects of hitting enemies doesn't have any umph to them either. The sound department as whole is severely lacking in this game.

Sometimes enemies will stop for a second and look at the screen and sort of "cheer". But for who? Me? Themselves? Feels really out of place. When you hit enemies you'll get text boxes like "Epic" or "Awesome" that pop up.  Sometimes it's really cringey stuff too...For example if you hit them with a baseball bat it shows, "Home Run", ugh. At the end of levels next to "Stage Clear" sometimes it will say dumb things like "Winner Winner Chicken Dinner". I'm not playing PUBG but thanks I guess??

I could never get the game to run full screen either. When I did launch the game it would launch a small window version and alt+enter wouldn't work to full size it. Tried changing different resolutions but nothing worked. I had to resort to using windowed mode which showed my taskbar the whole time.

Supposedly there is a third update coming, but it's been well over a year since that announcement and it's still not out. It may or may not come out at all, but at this point the dev might be done working on the game but who knows.

author: {'steamid': '76561198168687091', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 89, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 89, 'last_played': 1572474705}
review:
A classic 90's beat-them-up side-scrolling action game made with current technology of 3-D rendered background and characters. You know the game faithfully re-captures the feel of the genre when you see the first stage starts in a slum. The style and design of the enemies are also done correctly. It feels a little clunky, though. Not sure if it is done purposely to resemble the retro experience, as revisiting those games like Final Fight or Street of Rage now you may feel the control not very responsive, too. 

No visual options other than resolution, but any modern computer should have no problem running this game smoothly. While the high-def background scrolls smoothly, the also high-def character's actions are composed of only limited animation frames. This is a weird decision as the walking, punching, etc,. all look stiff. With  It feels like playing a 16-bit console like Genesis or SNES. This is a weird decision of retro design, though. The old consoles did so due to limited memory size. On those hardware with big memories like arcade or NEOGEO, same games typically had fluid animation for character actions in the old days. So there is no point to make the actions clunky for retro purpose, and obviously memory is no longer an issue for a new game like this. More frames for character actions this game would play much better.

Overall this is a decent game for its genre. If you have doubt, pick it up on sale and you can't go wrong.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001597265', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 215, 'playtime_forever': 475, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 110, 'last_played': 1653174302}
review:
This game is a pleasant surprise. Bought it 66% off at 5.95$ so take that into consideration .

I play this game using an xboxone controller, wich i recommend. There was no issue and buttons where decently mapped so i did not have to remap anything. Out of the box runs great.

 It is a game in the veins of classics like final fight and double dragons. Where it differs a bit, and it might be to it's advantage is that it isn't as cheap as these games. Understandably the afformentioned games wanted to kill you to get a new quarter ( pretty much all arcade games did that ). This one not so much so for a game that pays homage to the old beat em up games it is surprisingly fair thanks in no small part to the dash mechanic. By pressing left or right trigger button your character can dash through relatively unstopable attacks unscared. You can even form combos with it.

 You can see when you pay attention to small details that it was not just casually put together and while simple and not so long ( can be done in an hour or so ) what is there is fun. Game as a classic beat the stage and beat a boss mode and also one where you beat waves of enemies in one of 4 stages. There is always a fair ammount of weapons around for you to use so if you wished for more weapons when playing final fight well they probably wished for that too because here they are.

 The graphiqs are better than what i tought they would be by looking at the videos and screenshot altough i guess to each his own... I had a great time but if i have to note netagive i would say the music is very dull and forgetable although it is often the case in such games. Also enemies are very repetitive.

 Well there you are, buy the game it is worth it for 5-6$ that i paid i have a game that , sometimes, punches above it's pay grade.

review:
While it's far from perfect, there are definitely some good things going here. The gameplay is reminiscent of classic 90s brawlers like Final Fight, with lots of weapons and one tweak I always appreciate, being able to hit foes while they're down, and the "good cop/bad cop" theme gives you a couple ways to play. It runs well on PCs that meet or are just above minimum requirements, looks good too although some character movements seem a bit stiff. Also it feels like collision detection is slightly off, especially when trying to pick up weapons. Plays well with controllers although the in-game configuration/remapping option needs some fixes when trying to change control layouts. Haven't tried local multiplayer yet (no online, which is fine with me) but I like how there's a "friendly fire" option.
Overall it could be much better with a few tweaks/improvements, but so far there's enough to satisfy me and may be worth checking out if you like your brawlers violent with lots of weapons. There are better but if you don't care much for the pixel graphics trend (I'm not a fan of it) then this is definitely a winner in graphics with good gameplay. Slight thumbs up for now.

review:
Raging Justice Или Паразитирование На Ностальгии

Жанр beat`em и shoot`em up`а сегодня не частый гость, толи в конце 80-х - начале 90-х. Понятно, что сейчас аппаратная часть позволяет делать игры гораздо более сложные, чем двухмерная картинка, которая смещается по мере передвижения персонажа к краю экрана, чем и пользуются игроделы. Не знаю как вам, но мнн сильно нехватает простеньких спинно-мозговых игр с бодрым геймплеем, и неважно каким сюжетом. Но в послежнее время разработчики толи сами для себя, толи для таких ностальгирующих личностей как я выпускаю продукты различного качества. И если с Guns, gore and canoli - все хорошо как ни крути, то в Raging Justice дела обстоят несколько хуже. Разработчик старательно пытался передать стилистику подобных игр, выходивших на консолях в начале 90-х, со всех их плюсами и минусами, и это нужно признать, вышло прекрасно. Картинка несколько блеклая и мутноватая, но наверняка так и задумывалось, но гемплей бодрый и доовльно веселый - за час игра проходится. В двоем думается играть будет повеселее. Под конец правда несколько однообразный гемйплей надоаедает, но часок - это та продолжительность, которая и не даст вам заскучать, и не оставит вас с чувством разочарования "это и все ???!!"
Уровни не блещут разнообразием и интересными дизайнерскими элементами и герои тоже  не слишком интересные - баба нигга, какая-то короткостриженная педовка и белый мужик среднего возраста.

Оценка: несмотря на низкий балл  (5.5/10), а я и с большим ставил "не рекомендую" в отсутсвии подобного контента приходится рекомендовать, ведь на безрыбье, как говорится, и рак - рыба. Пока не выпустили Battletoads - играем в это...

 2x pra frente mais ataque :aqui é o pior...WTF vcs fizeram?! ?! Essa mistura de Dodge com ataque ė RIDÍCULA era melhor ver o filme do Pelé e deixar sem mesmo.

Hintergründe etc. sind langweilig und zum vergessen. 
Wenn das Kampfsystem wenigstens gelungen und spaßig wäre, dann wäre es ja halb so wild, aber auch das ist so monoton. Die wenigen Gegnertypen , die es gibt, lassen sich im Grunde alle mit den selben Kombos bearbeiten. Die Lebensleiste macht hierbei den größten Unterschied aus.
Gegnertypen: 
1. Gewöhnlicher Gangsta
2. Nutte (hat einen Taser)
3. Fettkloß (Hat eine Rammattacke)
4. Großer Typ in Trenchcoat (wirft ab und zu Dynamit, dass man zurückwirft oder ausweicht)
5. Großer Muskelprotz (hat einen aufgeladenen Schlag

author: {'steamid': '76561198050478003', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 197, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 132, 'last_played': 1562604119}
review:
My kind of game!

I am a huge fan of 2d beat em ups, and while there are a lot of them on Steam, very few are straight up no-nonsense street beat em ups. Most beat em ups nowadays have some kind of  RPG system which might be interesting for new gamers, but in my mind taints/changes the genre. It stops being "pick up and play" and about your skills and becomes more about leveling up and such. Double Dragon Neon for example, while being a great game, suffers from that. It's no longer beat em up, but some kind of hybrid. That's why I was always on the lookout for some pure beat em up where you are a bad dude trying to clean up the streets from various thugs. And if you are in need of a pure beat em up, look no further than Raging Justice!

It's a classic story about a corrupt city and 3 characters willing to take the law into their hands(fists). An old-school cop, ex-military chick, and an obligatory street kid form the team. You have punches, kicks, grabs(which can flow into punch/kick pummel or throw in a true Streets of Rage style), dashes(up and down like in Streets of Rage 3) and jumps. Apart from the blunt weapons and an occasional gun, there are also a few vehicles to drive around like tractors and lawnmowers. The game also has another feature I really loved is that the shortcuts for dashing (double tap normally) and special health-draining move (punch+kick) do exist for newer gamers but you do not have to use it if you want to play old-school, you can just use the combination of regular commands like in the old days. I've always felt old arcade games were better controlled with their simplicity than having 8 different buttons instead of the 3-4. Just because our gamepads nowadays have more buttons it does not mean we have to use them all.

It's not all familiar territory though - you see there is a "cop" aspect where you can bust bad guys after you stun them and then you get more health drops and points. The game (I think) randomly assigns a certain thug in each level that you have to arrest and you also have other "challenges" during the levels, such as collect a certain amount of cash or bust a certain number of bad guys. Naturally, there are hulking bosses and they also repeat in the end levels of the game like in the old arcade games. There is also a separate "survival" mode where you fight to survive many waves of street thugs.

Graphically the game looks detailed and with many sprite animations, but it depends on how do you feel about the digitalized look, that was all the rage in the mid 90's. Some people like it, some don't. I do. Music varies from being awesome to barely noticeable and is probably the weakest aspect of the game. Also, the game supports xinput gamepads for local multiplayer and while there are no graphical options to tweak, the game runs on any potato PC, disregard the blown up requirements on the Steam page.

For me this game was great because it was exactly what I was looking for - a pure street beat em up in the veins of Streets of Rage and Final Fight. If you think that is not enough and you would like something more, like leveling up stats, rogue-like progression, open world and such you're better off buying something else. But if you want to bash some thugs and pick up food from the seedy streets while being a tough cop - this is the game for you.

[quote][b]Para quem gosta de ler:[/b]

[h1]Pretensão atendida[/h1]
Raging Justice pretende trazer para os dias atuais a aura oitentista dos beat'n up das antigas, além do clima de filme policial com tiras durões que não cumprem a lei a risca, bandidos de gangs que metem o terror na cidade e uma história em que o prefeito está desaparecido e cabe aos protagonistas o encontrarem, de fase em fase, de chefe em chefe. O clima deu certo.

[h1]Gráficos:[/h1]
O estilo gráfico escolhido lembra muito a digitalização dos Mortal Kombat das antigas, porém com mais volume nos personagens. Também lembra um pouco jogos como Clayfighters e Killer Instinct pelo proposital FPS baixo das movimentações, resgatando nas animações dos personagens este estilo ousado para os dias de hoje. O cenário, muito bem trabalhado, parece muitas vezes fotografia de ambientes de filmes da década de 80. Os inimigos são bastante diferentes um do outro e existem bastante modelos, incorrendo nos clichês que o jogo pretende abordar, como mulheres com roupas de BDSM, punks, gordalhões que dão encontrão. Todos os elementos gráficos dos beat'n up oitentistas são encontrados em Raging Justice. São bacanas também as transições de cena, bem características, desenhadas e animadas em quadros, com manchetes de jornal, aquela coisa toda. Em uma comparação simples para saber se você vai gostar de um beat'n up oitentista com gráfico modernizado, pense no Super Mario World e depois no New Super Mario do Nintendo Wii. Se a modernização gráfica de um para o outro lhe agradou, provavelmente você vai gostar desta repaginada gráfica que a MakinGames Ltd deu no gênero e a Team17 Digital abraçou.

[h1]Som:[/h1]
A trilha sonora é boa, com slaps de baixo e rock bem oitentistas, porém em algumas partes ficam um poucos deslocadas, pelo fato de parecer não ser colocada apropriadamente nos momentos corretos. No geral funciona, mas ocorre com frequência de rolar uns slaps de baixo mais calmos em momentos de pancadaria ou algo mais pesado em momentos mais calmos. Mas eu escrevi acima, no geral, funciona bem. As músicas em si parecem ter sido retiradas de clássicos policiais da sessão da tarde, o que certamente vai agradar quem jogava os beat'n up da época e assistia essas pérolas na TV de tubo. Os efeitos sonoros são normais para o gênero, sons de soco, chute e pauladas. Nada muito a declarar deste quesito. 

[h1] Jogabilidade:[/h1]
Existem 3 personagens para escolher e, como na maioria dos jogos do gênero, um é mais pesadão de controlar, porém é mais forte, tem uma mina mais rápida e mais fluída, e um moleque travesso bem ágil porém fraco. Comecei a jogatina na live com o primeiro, e reclamei bastante da jogabilidade, não gostando muito de início. Após morrer todos os continues, optei pela personagem feminina e aí sim comecei a gostar da jogabilidade. Parecia outro jogo. Com golpes rápidos, além de ficar mais fácil manejar, foi muito mais divertido e o mesmo se deu com o moleque. Sobre os botões, os clássicos do gênero também: soco, chute, pulo (com voadora se apertar o chute no ar), agarrão e um especial que consome HP mas mata a galera na volta. Em algumas fases é possível pegar veículos para sair atropelando os inimigos, o que é muito divertido :) Os chefes são difíceis de matar até encontrar o padrão de cada um, mas depois vai. 

[h1]Diversão:[/h1]
No geral, a jogabilidade é coerente com o que pretende o jogo. De início, em razão da inovação gráfica para o gênero, demora um pouco para acostumar, mas é aquele tipo de jogo que, dando uma segunda chance, o negócio flui e diverte.

[h1] Conclusão: [/h1]
Pancadaria em beat'n up dificilmente não diverte para quem gosta do gênero. Neste caso, o gráfico bem elaborado, a trilha oitentista e a jogabilidade fluída (com a ressalva do primeiro personagem), aliando a dificuldade clássica trazida da década de 80, com continues, desafios para cumprir em cada fase e uma história clichê pra quem curte o clima, Raging Justice é um projeto ousado que deu certo. Pode não agradar a todos old school gamers, bem como também não agradar os atuais, pelas suas inovações técnicas, colocando-o em um limbo neutro onde gamers velhos torçam o nariz para os gráficos e os novos não entendam a proposta. Mas basta um pouquinho de investimento mental e deixar os pré conceitos de lado que o novo vai fazer muito bem e garantir algumas horas de jogatina e diversão.
[/quote]

review:
Raging Justice is a classically inspired side-scrolling beat-em-up both inside and out.  What's particularly noteworthy is its arrival comes over two decades after the genre was last considered hot.  While the contemporary release date is likely enough to drive most fans interest, the question ultimately becomes whether there's a good game to be had here or not.  After having played and (mostly) enjoyed the game for several hours, my answer is yes but with some very clear caveats.

If I had to put my finger squarely on what Raging Justice is trying to accomplish, it's pushing to be a reimagining and/or spiritual successor to entries in the Final Fight and Streets of Rage series overall.  From the gritty back allies and junkyard landscapes, to the abandoned fun fair and mansion that players will visit later on, the game attempts to capture the classic "street brawler" atmosphere of late 80's / early 90's arcade blockbusters that were chewing up quarters while simultaneously feasting on players frustrations.  For the most part it's a successful realization of this formula complete with an array of punks and criminals, pallete swapped accordingly for further enemy diversity.

That's to say, Raging Justice looks, feels, and plays like your typical arcade side-scrolling brawler with all the cheap hits, questionable AI, and "hey! that's just not fair" gameplay of its forefathers from decades gone by.  You *will* get double, triple, and even quadruple teamed with enemies coming at you from all sides, even on the "Wimp" difficulty.  You'll marvel at how the blast radius from a stick of dynamite half a screen over even touched you, let alone knocked you to the ground and robbed so much of your precious health.  You'll seethe at being unable to get a hit in as the millisecond you arise from a knockdown, one of the 6 to 8 (or more) on-screen enemies will have already knocked you down... again... for the 5th time in a row.

With time, skill and progression, you'll likely get better though.  This amounts to learning the quirks of the game and eventually figuring out a strategy to effectively cheat the game worse than the game cheats you.  So goes the classic beat-em-up genre, so goes Raging Justice.

While not quite commensurate with 2018 industry standards, the visuals in Raging Justice are a decent mix of contemporary graphical techniques and throwback Final Fight-esque presentation.  While the game won't win any awards in the eye candy department, what's on offer here is more than serviceable and, again, hearkens back to the time when the genre was at its hottest.  This also includes some stilted, stuttery animation throughout.  The harshest critics will likely claim that it has to do with unexplainable performance issues the game is incurring, while genre fans/apologists will offer "true to its roots" as the more likely explanation.

The music and sound effects really don't strike me one way or the other.  While there's nothing here that I would consider downright bad, there's also nothing that really stands out either.  Said differently, the audio samples and *especially* the music from both Final Fight and Streets of Rage remain quite memorable some 20+ years later.  Those featured in Raging Justice... not so much.

While the developer gets bonus points for trying something new, the Good Cop (arrest) / Bad Cop (kill) dynamic ultimately feels tacked on and out of place in such a frenzied, sometimes panic driven game.  Raging Justice often downright refuses to cooperate with the mechanic even in the simplest of scenarios with limited enemies and weapons flying at you.  By the time you hit the third or fourth stage, you'll probably forget it's even there, save for the end-level stats reminding you that you failed yet another arrest-based challenge.

Flaws and all, Raging Justice is certainly worth a go for longtime fans of the beat-em-up genre.  Team 17 / MakinGames did their homework on what made those older releases equal parts frustrating and fun and did a solid job matching their game up accordingly.  For those new to the scene, I'd advise taking in at least a few YouTube videos before deciding to hit the purchase button.  The main reason new releases in the genre are so few and far between is because the format hasn't evolved (or, more accurately, has failed in the attempt) over time.  Despite some new mechanics and a new-ish coat of paint, Raging Justice likely won't convince newcomers or previous naysayers that beat-em-ups are officially back.  For those of us old enough to still remember though, Raging Justice successfully scratches an itch that's been mostly ignored (save for fan-made games) since the last iterations of Final Fight and Streets of Rage were new.

Raging Justice é um Beat'em Up retrô ambientado em uma cidade recheada de crime e corrupção, onde você deverá levar justiça às ruas.

A jogabilidade é um tanto simples, com 4 botões: soco, chute, pulo e agarramento, e só. Não há combos pomposos, nem poderes especiais, bloqueio ou grandes esquivas, tudo bem clássico do gênero.

Fora esses recursos, você tem ainda o lendário golpe que faz perder vida (apertando soco e chute), e um ataque com corrida, dando dois toques para esquerda ou direita.

O jogo te dará a oportunidade de prender os inimigos, ou simplesmente nocauteá-los. Esse sistema é um dos grande diferenciais do jogo, que te permite jogar como um tira bom ou mau. Para prender um inimigo você deverá deixá-lo tonto, e então aproximar-se e apertar o botão de arremesso.

A campanha é composta por 9 fases, sempre com um chefe desafiador ao final de cada uma. Você também terá vidas e continues limitados durante a campanha, como em jogos clássicos do gênero.

O diferencial é que é possível reiniciar a campanha a partir de qualquer fase passada, e o jogo manterá a melhor quantidade de vidas/continues que você tinha quando iniciou aquela fase em questão.

Outra questão é que cada fase possui vários objetivos a serem cumpridos, como prender um número de inimigos, ou certos inimigos em questão.

Supostamente o jogo conta com no mínimo dois finais distintos, e levam em conta se você foi um bom ou mau policial durante a campanha.

A cooperação é apenas local para 3 jogadores, com direito a drop-in, e possibilidade de ativar ou desativar o fogo amigo.

Recomendado a fãs de clássicos do gênero, que buscam uma experiência moderna porém próxima aos jogos arcadescos que deram origem aos Beat'em Ups!

review:
Growing up in the 80s and 90s in a boardwalk town with 5+ arcades, I sure did spend alot of time playing Beat em' Ups.
Raging Justice does two things for me which many of the great Beat em' Ups do.

-Its a good time and fun to play.
-I find myself thinking about it and wanting to play it when I'm not playing it.

Many of my favorite Beat em' Ups keep me coming back over 20 years later. Simply because they are fun to play and they made a lasting impression. 
Final Fight, The Punisher, TMNT, Armored Warriors, Battle Circuit, X-Men, Sengoku.. and so on.. I can be having a normal day when suddenly I am hit with nostalgia flashback of any of these games and I need to fire them up and reply them as soon as possible.
Now, I'm not saying Raging Justice will still have people playing it in 20 years, but current at week of release, for the first time in a long time, I am excited to play a new Beat em' Up.

The gameplay might feel sluggish at first. It kinda reminded me of Sengoku 3. At first in both games, things just feel a bit uncomfortable. But once it clicks and you're used to it, you'll be racking up combos and beating down enemies with no issue. My first play thru I didnt even make it to the final stage. Played the Brawl mode for some pratice. My second play thru I easily got to stage 8 without using a continue, and hit a 75 hit combo along the way. Sweet.
An enjoyable game which will keep me coming back for more.

The arrest feature is super cool. Adds alot to the gameplay. The ability to arrest makes it easy to quickly eliminate enemies which may be bothersome to you, without having to completely beat them down.
Also, the stage by stage achievements and arrest warrents.. I love it. Another reason to keep me coming back. Its fun to build up your own playing abilities to the point where you can whoop on everyone while trying to hit every stage achievement.

Only really one thing I would change if I could. I love grapple/wrestler characters. Would love a character with more bulk and played a more throw and slam oriented fighting style.

review:
seriously, this one took me by surprise. I've tried to find in my quest today's beat-em up versions of the streets of rage series and this is the closest of them all. It's literally streets of rage 4. well, sort of. However, it does have its quirks and issues. For one thing I can't understand for the life of me why developers think it's necessary to to stuff the screen with loads of AI enemies that, chock full of them don't give you breathing space or the time to pull off neat combo tricks. It can get really cluttered on screen. it becomes infuriating being knocked down every second. I can't remember streets of rage being cluttered or getting my head kicked in every second.
Also the the characters animations is like figgety like their missing a frame or two. the game needs more ironing out.
Nevertheless, saying all this. I was literally hooked to the game. It certainly made me feel like going back it time. 
I would definitely recommend this game to streets of rage / final fight fans of the genre. It's definitely one of the best so far.

Finally, I can confirm this works out of the box in wine Linux with 3.xx staging on Ubuntu 16.04. No extra DLLs required to install.

review:
I thought I'd really like this game, but it just doesn't feel right to me. I don't know if it will come to me with a bit more play, but the combat doesnt flow nicely, it feels a bit clunky. 
I don't really get on with the controls either, and want to remap the buttons, but I don't think you can, the options are very limited to what you can actually alter, and I would like to think that they will add more at a later date. You can't even set the resolution!
The music seems bland, and has just stopped working when I've been playing some levels for no apparent reason. 
The other thing that gets on my t its, is the camera constantly wobbling around and zooming in and out, up and down. It's like a bad episode of Hollyoaks. And the way that you can't dash left or right if you're holding a weapon, but you can up and down. And you can'teven  swap character when you continue!

Give me some options to fix the camera, and remap the controls, and I might manage to make it through the game, but as it is, I'm not sure if I'll see it through to the end.

I do like the vehicles though, so it's not all bad. I just think my expectations were a little high. I wouldn't rate this anywhere near as good as any of the Streets of Rage, or even Golden Axe. Personally, for relativlyey newish scrolling beat 'em up I'd reccomend Streets of Fury EX, or Mother Russia Bleeds. If i had bought it through Steam, I'd have probably requested a refund, but I got it on Humble Bundle a bit cheaper, so I'm stuck with it. I just hope it does get some improvements made, as I think it's got the potential to be very good.

I knew exactly what to expect about this game. I was born in the 80's. Street of Rage, Final Fight and the TMNT games are part of my DNA. This game was made practically by 2 people who I would love to have a cup of coffee with, because I feel they understand me. That they know me so well... because the game is amazing. It's everything we, Beat-em-Ups lovers would want from a game like this. This is more than retro, this is a love letter to the genre! 

Raging Justice is beautiful to look at and the Good Cop / Bad Cop system is really cool and original. The gameplay sometimes feels like it could be a little bit smoother but nothing that ruins the experience. It is still, above all, a solid game in terms of gameplay. 

I played the game when it was released and right after I finished it, I remembered thinking that I would love to have support for a third player and sometimes the game is really tough but hey. The developers fixed this with an update that not only added the possibility 3 player co-op but also did some adjustments on the difficulty. That's what I called "listening to the community!" 

If you'd like to feel back in the 90´s again, do yourself a favor and buy this game. Buy it mostly to support the developers, support their both your passion and theirs! Let people know that this genre NEEDS to comeback and this is the much needed testament: it is fun and one of the best couch co-op experiences.

Fantastic, classic beat 'em up. Love the art style. Really dig the vibe and ambiance too. 

Played 3 stages so far. Mechanically no issues. Each stage was kept fresh to avoid the monotony plagued by the bad titles in the genre. 

For the negative:
 1) Overall player movement could be sped up a little. Hard to pull off the dash, especially using a stick on a xbox pad. Little stiff - more fluidity would be nice and hopefully addressed in an update. 
2) Can get a little too reliant on crowd control button to avoid getting pummeled by a group of thugs at times. If #1 is addressed somehow, it would help this issue as well maybe.

I miss games like this. Pick it up if you're a fan of any of the other great side scrolling beat 'em ups to come out in the last decade like:

Double Dragon Neon (really, really good)
Castle Crashers
Fight 'n Rage
Foul Play
Mother Russia Bleeds

author: {'steamid': '76561198001507954', 'num_games_owned': 3199, 'num_reviews': 302, 'playtime_forever': 220, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 219, 'last_played': 1529752528}
review:
[h1]Raging Justice[/h1]

Raging Justice is an over-the-top sidescrolling beat'emup full of modern machismo in the best way possible. Paying homage to the pioneers of brawlers this very much resembles a 3D Streets of Rage or Final Fight, down to the dramatic openings of still-frame dystopic city scenes and corrupt kingpins.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

The punches, kicks, grabs and even those fun overpowered little jump-kicks you always use to abuse as a kid in brawlers are all here in fast, slick combo-y order. The three characters you have to choose from offer a pretty standard balance right out the gate; The grizzled old veteran cop is slow and lumbering but powerful, the spunky street kid is nimble and quick, and the bad ass military lady is a nice even middle ground.

All form of interesting and explosive weaponry and devices litter these crude and dangerous city streets as you smash and bash your way through the hordes of miscreants and outlaws, and are honestly the most satisfying way to fight. From the typical bats, crowbars, trashcans, and knives to more unconvential and crazy explosives and electrifying stunguns. Later on vehicles are even thrown into the mix for players to ride and cause destruction in, for even more thug-steamrolling mayhem and fun.

Raging Justice brings a lot more to the table than just the rinse and repeat beatemup motions of brawlers we all already know. New is the clever and engaging Good Cop-Bad Cop system giving you a bit of choice and flexibility in how you deal with the various thugs and hooligans of the streets. As enemies have their health chipped away they become stunned, and your choice is to either continue beating on them until death or incapacitate them with handcuffs for a successful arrest. Killing suspects gets you bad points and arrests get you good points, and the various outcomes of your playthrough are altered by which role you decide to play.

To keep things even more interesting every level has a list of challenges for you to gain some extra points and credit by completing, with all of these quirks in mind. Hitting a quota of required arrests will clear you a challenge by playing it cool and pacifying criminals instead of killing them, using specific weapons with certain objectives in mind can gain you another, and other obvious quirks like beating stages under a specified time or with a certain highscore obtained fill in the blanks for other interesting challenges all to spice up the game and give incentive for those future replays with a friend.

[h1]Visuals/Sound[/h1]

The sound here is absolute 80's fanfare. The heavy, funky synth bass does give a strong Sega Genesis vibe but the compositions are far from Yuzo Koshiro's quality of dirty and grimey electro. They have a classic bad-boy 80's street gang kind of movie vibe to them honestly, not too far off from something you'd hear in MJ's Thriller.

Raging Justice is a strange visual hybrid of high-fidelity graphics mixed with appropriately choppy retro animation, making it look almost akin to one of those stop-motion fighters of the 90's like Primal Rage, MK3 or even Clayfighters. It'll either draw you in with its hypnotizing strangeness and nostalgic originality or gross you out with its brash and not very fluid presentation. 

This is definitely going to be a "love it or hate it" kind of situation as far as the visuals go, mostly relying on your fondness or your disdain for outside-the-box experimental visual styles of the past. Either way, the urban atmosphere of the backgrounds is a nice and authentically old school one.

[h1]Final Thought[/h1]

An original and memorable modernized 3D style make it pretty easy to believe this was crafted by minds who had previously worked at the iconic Rare studios, a pleasant surprise to realize halfway through getting into this madcap urban brawler.

As with any brutal beat'em'up the badassery is doubled with a friend at your side for that sweet couch co-op, so be sure to bring another Crude Dude (or Dudette) along for the romp!
